payload.name: reflective-equilibrium
payload.core: Iteratively adjust both abstract principles and concrete case judgments until they cohere. Neither theory nor intuition has automatic priority; both evolve together through mutual revision.
out: coherent_principles: general rules that accommodate considered judgments
case_decisions: specific judgments consistent with principles
proc: articulate initial principles and intuitive case judgments
identify tensions between principles and judgments
consider revising principle to accommodate strong intuition
consider revising judgment to honor compelling principle
iterate until no further revisions improve coherence
document final equilibrium with justification for each adjustment
check: principles and judgments stated explicitly before revision
each revision justified by coherence gain
difficult cases genuinely addressed not quietly dropped
trade-offs documented when perfect coherence impossible

diff.deductive: deduction derives conclusions from fixed axioms; reflective equilibrium allows axioms to change
diff.moral-ethical: moral reasoning applies normative content; reflective equilibrium is the method for refining that content
diff.dialectical: dialectic synthesizes opposing views; reflective equilibrium iterates between theory and cases
diff.belief-revision: belief revision updates beliefs given evidence; reflective equilibrium updates principles given judgments and vice versa

signals: principles only tested on easy examples
mitigations: maintain explicit list of difficult cases
require justification for each excluded case
revisit equilibrium when new hard cases arise

use: policy design balancing general rules with edge cases

steps: case judgment: fraud detection needs behavioral data
tension: principle conflicts with legitimate use case
revised principle: minimize unnecessary data; define necessary as required for stated service purpose
tested against more cases: marketing analytics fails; security logging passes
equilibrium: principle now coherent with considered judgments on 12 test cases
